questions.text: Which of the following is the most common non alcoholic cause of acute pancreatitis? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Alcohol and gall stones are the two most important causes of pancreatitis. Hypercalcemia and hyperlipidemia are also the causes of pancreatitis but the not more common causes. Causes: • The major causes are long-standing alcohol intake or biliary stone disease. • Medications: azathioprine, corticosteroids, sulfonamides, thiazides, furosemides, NSAIDs, mercaptopurine, methyldopa, tetracyclines DDI (dideoxycytosine), DDC (dideoxyinosine), azathioprine, valproic acid, acetaminophen, and others. • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). • Hypertriglyceridemia: When the triglyceride level exceeds 1000mg/U. • Peptic ulcer disease. • Abdominal or cardiopulmonary bypass surgery: insulting the gland by ischemia. • Trauma to the abdomen or to the back. • Carcinoma of the pancreas, which may lead to pancreatic outflow obstruction. • Viral infections: cytomegalovirus, hepatitis virus, EBV, CMV and paramyxovirus [mumps], togavirus [rubella], cytomegalovirus, adenovirus, HIV, coxsackie B. • Bacterial infections, such as Mycoplasma, Campylobacter, Legionella, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, M. avium complex. • Intestinal parasites: Ascaris, Opisthorchis [clonorchiasis], which blocks outflow. • Pancreas divisum. • Black Scorpion and snake bites. • Vascular factors, such as ischemia or vasculitis, Connective-tissue disorders (SLE, polyarteritisnodosa, sarcoidosis). • Drugs: 5- Aminosalicylic acid, Azathiopine, 6 Mercaptopeurine, Thiazide, steroid, Pentamidine, Metronidazole, Valproic acid, L-Asparaginase, Zidovudine. Objective measurements such as Ranson’s criteria, show a good correlation with the risk of major complications and death.

questions.text: Most common complication after ERCP is: (AIIMS May 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) COMPLICATIONS OF ERCP • Complications: Pancreatitis, hemorrhage, cholangitis and perforation. • MC complication is acute pancreatitis (5%) • Hemorrhage requires surgical intervention most commonly, sphincterotomy usually is converted into formal surgical sphincteroplasty, which includes the bleeding artery . • Cholangitis is confined to patients in whom CBD clearance has not been achieved, and measures should be directed at providing adequate bile drainage and administering parenteral antibiotics. Emergency surgery for cholangitis carries high risk, but is indicated in patients who do not improve within 24 hours. • Perforation may be asymptomatic and noticed only as retroperitoneal gas or extravasation of radiographic contrast material, but even in symptomatic patient, conservative treatment is often effective with spontaneous resolution and avoidance of potentially difficult surgery.

questions.text: Post-operative pancreatitis is seen in which type of surgery? (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cardiopulmonary Bypass Post-operative pancreatitis is a known complication that can arise after various surgical procedures. While some cases are linked to direct mechanical trauma during surgery or changes in gastrointestinal physiology, it is also significantly associated with surgical interventions that impact systemic perfusion or induce a widespread inflammatory response. Cardiopulmonary Bypass (CPB), commonly used in complex cardiac surgeries, involves temporarily stopping the heart and lungs while a machine takes over their functions. This process often leads to periods of low systemic perfusion (reduced blood flow to organs throughout the body) and can trigger a systemic inflammatory response. These physiological changes are recognized mechanisms that can lead to acute pancreatitis in the post-operative period. The provided explanation explicitly states, "Pancreatitis also can occur in association with surgery that uses low systemic perfusion, such as cardiopulmonary bypass and cardiac transplantation." This directly affirms the association. Incorrect Options: A. Billroth type I: While gastrectomies (like Billroth I or II) involve abdominal surgery and can be associated with pancreatitis (especially Billroth II due to changes in duodenal pressure), Billroth I itself is not highlighted as a primary or distinct cause of pancreatitis due to low systemic perfusion, which is the mechanism linked to CPB in the provided context. B. Splenectomy: Pancreatitis can indeed be a complication of splenectomy, primarily due to the close anatomical proximity of the spleen to the tail of the pancreas, making it susceptible to direct surgical injury. However, the question and the provided explanation specifically highlight "low systemic perfusion" as a mechanism, which is characteristic of CPB, not direct trauma from splenectomy. C. Nephrectomy: This is the surgical removal of a kidney. While theoretically possible due to proximity of the left kidney to the pancreas, post-operative pancreatitis is an extremely rare complication of an uncomplicated nephrectomy and is not typically associated with the mechanism of "low systemic perfusion" like CPB.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is the answer to this question as Investigation of choice for the retroperitoneal structures like pancreas is CECT . CT scan is the most reliable imaging modality in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. The criteria for the diagnosis are divided by Balthazar and colleagues into 5 grades. • Grade A: Normal pancreas. • Grade B: Focal or diffuse gland enlargement. • Grade C: Intrinsic gland abnormality seen by haziness on the scan. • Grade D: Single ill-defined collection or phlegmon. • Grade E: Two or more ill-defined collections or the presence of gas in or nearby, the pancreas. USG is the first investigation or the screening tool for the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. ERCP is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: Management of pancreatic abscess is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) STERILE AND INFECTED PERIPANCREATIC FLUID COLLECTIONS (PANCREATIC ABSCESS) • The presence of acute abdominal fluid during an episode of AP has been described in 30-57% of patients. • In contrast to pseudocysts and cystic neoplasias of the pancreas, fluid collections are not surrounded or encased by epithelium or fibrotic capsule. • Treatment is supportive because most fluid collections will be spontaneously reabsorbed by the peritoneum. • Pancreatic Abscess: The presence of fever, elevated WBC count, and abdominal pain suggest infection of this fluid and percutaneous aspiration is confirmatory. • Percutaneous drainage and IV administration of antibiotics should be instituted if infection (pancreatic abscess) is present.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of pancreatic ascites? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pancreatic ascites occurs from a pancreatic duct disruption or from a leaking pseudocyst. • High amylase levels are found in the ascitic fuid and pancreatic ascites is an exudate due to inflammation and hence it is rich in proteins. • Initial treatment: Non-operative (elimination of enteral feeding, institution of nasogastric drainage, and administration of somatostatin) • Repeat paracentesis may also be helpful. • Roughly 50% to 60% of patients can be expected to respond to this treatment with resolution of pancreatic ascites within 2 to 3 weeks.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is wrong as if we have infected pancreatic necrosis we have to do some intervention as infected necrotic tissue wont resolve on its own just by observation and antibiotics alone. Once infection has been demonstrated, IV antibiotics should be given. Because of their penetration into the pancreas and spectrum coverage, carbapenems (imipenem and meropenem) are the first option of treatment. Defnitive treatment for infected pancreatic necrosis is surgical debridement with mucosectomy, closed continuous irrigation, and open packaging. Option A that is percutaneous drainage can be done by the time pancreatic necrosectomy is planned. Option D is a universal thing to build up the patient preoperatively as pancreatic surgery is a major stress for patient’s body and it should be able to withstand this stress.

questions.text: All are true about pancreatic fistula except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) PANCREATICOENTERIC FISTULA • Pancreatic pseudocysts or areas of pancreatic necrosis can erode into the small intestine, duodenum, stomach, bile duct, or splenic flexure of the colon. • Occasionally, this results in resolution of the pseudocyst, and no further treatment is needed. • More often, such an event is accompanied by significant bleeding or signs of sepsis, and surgical intervention is usually required. • Management of these fistulas is determined by the gastrointestinal organ involved

questions.text: Most common symptom of chronic pancreatitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clinical Manifestations: The clinical picture of chronic pancreatitis is dominated by three features; abdominal pain, maldigestion, and diabetes (loss of exocrine and endocrine pancreatic function). The pain is localized to the upper abdomen, with radiation to subcostal regions and to the back. The pain is aggravated by meals and improves with fasting. When more than 90% of exocrine pancreatic function is lost, maldigestion and malabsorption ensue. This is manifested by steatorrhea (fat malabsorption) associated with diarrhea and bloating, azotorrhea (protein malabsorption) and progressive weight loss. These patients frequently present with loss of adipose tissue, judged by hanging skin folds, and more objectively by demonstrating that the skin fold at the mid-triceps is less than 8 mm in males and less than 12 mm in females. Latent fat-soluble vitamin deficiency (vitamins A, D, E and K) in addition to deficiencies of magnesium, calcium and essential fatty acids may occur and are closely related to dysfunction of fat digestion. Endocrine insufficiency presenting as diabetes mellitus may present at the same time as exocrine insufficiency or a few years later.

questions.text: Causes of chronic tropical pancreatitis is: (LQ)

Cassava root contains toxic glycosides,which increases susceptibility to free radical injury of the pancreas, this predisposes and leads to tropical pancreatitis.

questions.text: The most likely cause of fluctuating jaundice in a middle aged or elderly man is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) fluctuating jaundice is a typical feature of periampullary carcinoma . What happens in periampullary carcinoma is that tumour increases in size and a point comes when the arterial supply to the tumour is not able reach till the tip and thus the distal most portion undergoes necrosis and sloughs off . When tumour was large in size it causes obstructive jaundice and as soon as the tumour gets sloughed off, the jaundice gets relieved and this leads waxing and weaning of jaundice over a period of 2-3 months. Option B that is Liver fluke infestation is not a cause of intermittent jaundice. Option C that is choledochal cyst presents with pain lump and jaundice and the jaundice is not intermittent. Option D that is carcinoma head of pancreas presents with jaundice but in this case the jaundice is not intermittent it a persistent jaundice.

questions.text: Migratory thrombophlebitis seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Malignancies associated with Migratory Thrombophlebitis:- CA pancreas (MC) Prostate cancer CA lung Ovarian cancer GI malignancies Lymphoma Trousseau’s syndrome: Migratory thrombophlebitis Trousseau’s sign: Carpopedal spasm in hypocalcemia Troisier’s sign: Palpable left supraclavicular LN (Virchow’s node)

questions.text: A 55 years old male presents with features of obstructive jaundice. He also reports a weight loss of seven kilograms in last two months. On CT scan, the CBD is dilated till the lower end and the main pancreatic duct is also dilated.Pancreas is normal. The most likely diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Patient has presented with obstructed jaundice and loss of weight. On CT scan we see CBD and main pancreatic duct is dilated. Pancreas is normal. These finding favour the diagnosis of periampullary carcinoma . Option A is not the answer as choledocholithiasis can present as obstructive jaundice but it will not lead to dilated main pancreatic duct. Option B that is carcinoma gall bladder rarely leads to obstructive jaundice and if at all it does, it occurs at a very late stage. Main pancreatic duct is almost never dilated in gall bladder carcinoma. Option C that is hilar cholangiocarcinoma presents with obstructive jaundice but there is no dilated main pancreatic duct in these patients.

questions.text: Inverted “3” sign seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer as inverted 3 sign is seen in ampullary carcinoma . Frostberg inverted 3 sign is a radiological sign seen on a barium examination where there is effacement and distortion of the mucosal pattern on the medial wall of the second part of the duodenum due to focal mass and local oedema. It is most commonly associated with Ampullary carcinoma but can also be seen in duodenal carcinoma and pancreatitis.

questions.text: The commonest pancreatic tumor is (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) the most common pancreatic tumour is ductal adenocarcinoma . Option B that is cystadenoma is another tumour but is not the most common one. Option C that is insulinoma is a functional endocrine tumour of Pancreas but is less common as compared to adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Most sensitive investigation of pancreatic carcinoma is: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) CT scan is the best investigation to look for any pancreatic pathology and this includes pancreatic carcinoma. Investigation of choice for carcinoma pancreas: MDCT Currently CT is probably the single most versatile and cost effective tool for diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: Most important predictor of post-operative survival in CA pancreas: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) R0 resection is the most important predictor of post operative survival in Ca pancreas. R0 resection means microscopic clearance of the tumour and the most important margin which needs to be resected while doing the operation is one along superior mesenteric vein

questions.text: Most common primary leading to secondaries in pancreas: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metastatic Tumors to Pancreas : Malignant melanoma > >>RCC On autopsy, MC site of primary: CA lung.

questions.text: Most common complication of Whipple's procedure is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Morbidity following Pancreaticoduodenectomy :- Delayed gastric emptying (18%) Cardiac events (3%) Pancreas fistula (12) Bile leak (2%) wound infection (7%) Overall reoperation (3%) Intra-abdominal abscess (6%)

choices.text: Pain is early in the course of the disease

questions.text: A patient with obstructive jaundice due to pancreatic cancer might have all of the following clinical findings except: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In Ca Pancreas, Symptoms include unexplained episodes of pancreatitis, painless jaundice, nausea, vomiting, steatorrhea, and unexplained weight loss With further spread beyond the pancreas, these patients may note upper abdominal or back pain when peripancreatic nerve plexuses are involved and ascites when peritoneal carcinomatosis or portal vein occlusion develops.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been found to increase the survival in locally advanced pancreatic cancer? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gemcitabine is currently the standard of care for patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: Middle segment pancreatectomy avoided in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Middle pancreatectomy is a safe, effective procedure for treatment of benign and low grade malignant neoplasms of the mid pancreas. Indications of Middle or Segmental Pancreatectomy • Benign or low grade malignant tumour (Neuroendocrine tumours, serous cystadenoma, branch duct IPMNs). • Location in the neck or its contiguous portion. • A distal pancreas stump of at least 5 cm in length.

questions.text: Components of Whipple's operation are following except? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Duodenojejunostomy is done in PPPD, not in Whipple’s procedure. Gastrojejunostomy is done in Whipple’s procedure.

questions.text: The preferred bypass procedure in case of non resectable carcinoma of head of pancreas is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct answer (D):- PALLIATIVE SURGERY IN ADVANCED, NON-RESECTABLE PANCREATIC ADENOCARCINOMA Surgery for advanced, non-resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma can palliate obstruction of CBD or duodenum, as well as control visceral pain. Hepaticojejunostomy, choledochojejunostomy or choledochoduodenostomy offers durable drainage of an obstructed bile duct. Cholecystojejunostomy is less reliable but can be employed when tumor bulk precludes common duct procedure. Gastrojejunostomy (antecolic anastomosis) palliates gastric outlet obstruction. Antecolic anastomosis is done to avoid complications from an expanding lesser sac tumour.

questions.text: Best prognosis for carcinoma of pancreas is in the region of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Periampullary cancer is a cancer that forms near the ampulla of Vater, an enlargement of the ducts from the liver and pancreas where they join and enter the small intestine. Best prognosis for ca of pancreas is periampullary ca.

Option B is correct as in these both benign and malignant variety are seen these are regarded as low grade malignant tumours. Option C is correct as solid pseudopapillary tumours are tumours with low grade malignant potential and are indolent tumours with Option D is false as solid pseudopapillary tumours are not positive for chromogranin.

questions.text: Best method of localization of insulinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is correct as the best method to localize insulinoma is EUS with intra-operative palpation. Option B that is MRI and dynamic CT is not used to localize insulinoma. Option C that is Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is not used to localize insulinoma. Option D that is CECT is also not used to localize insulinoma. Best method of pre-operative localization of insulinoma is intraarterial calcium injection with portal venous blood sampling.

questions.text: A 55-years old male presents with tachycardia, sweating, palpitation, giddiness. Most probable diagnosis: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Insulinoma produces symptoms of sympathetic overactivity which comprise of tachycardia, palpitation, tremors and excessive sweating. Option B not the answer to this question as Zollinger Ellison syndrome is caused by excessive secretion of gastrin leading to excessive gastric acid secretion. Option C is carcinoma pancreas and this presents with weight loss and fatigue and in some cases obstructive jaundice. Option D that is Carcinoid presents with symptoms of excessive serotonin secretion like flushing and palpitation.

questions.text: All are true about insulinoma except: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer to this question as insulinomas are mostly symptomatic and need to be treated by medicines and surgical interventions. Option B is correct as insulinomas are small and multiple and equally distributed in head, body and tail. Option C is correct as diazoxide and octreotide reduce insulin synthesis and are used in preoperative period to reduce the insulin synthesis. Option D is correct as most common site of insulinoma is pancreas Option E is correct as 90% of insulinomas are benign and need only enucleation as the treatment procedure.

choices.text: Common equally in the pancreatic head, body and tail

questions.text: True about insulinoma is all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is false as insulinoma does not present with weight loss rather it presents with weight gain. The reason being that these patients tends to eat more food prophylactically to prevent the occurrence of hypoglycaemia. So patient ends up eating more food and tends to be obese. Option A is correct as insulinoma is equally distributed in head, body and tail of pancreas. Option B is correct as hypoglycaemia is one of the key occurrences of insulinoma. D is correct as hypoglycaemia responds well to glucose infusion as a treatment option.

questions.text: Gold standard test for insulinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 72 hour fasting test is the gold standard test for diagnosing insulinoma, in this we look for hypoglycaemia to develop and look for features like tachycardia, palpitation, tremors, sweating, dizziness and headache. Option B that is plasma insulin levels is not used for the diagnosis of insulinoma as they can be raised even in exogenous injection of insulin. Option C that is C-peptide levels are used to rule out factitious hypoglycaemia as C-paptide is formed only in case of endogenous secretion of insulin. Option D is false as low glucose level can occur in any case and is not diagnostic of insulinoma.

questions.text: A lady presented with recurrent attacks of giddiness and abdominal pain since three months. Endoscopy was normal. Her fasting blood glucose was 40 mg% and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a well defined 8 mm enhancing lesion in the head of pancreas, with no other abnormal findings. What should be the treatment plan for this patient? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This case scenario describes a patient who has recurrent attacks of giddiness, and abdominal pain for 3 months. Has hypoglycaemia with raised insulin levels, CT scan shows a 8 mm lesion in the head of the pancreas. This patient has findings which point towards insulinoma as the diagnosis. As insulinoma is a benign tumour enucleation is the treatment of choice for insulinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common endocrine tumour of pancreas? (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) the most common functional endocrine tumour of pancreas is insulinoma. In fact the most common NET tumour of pancreas is the non functioning tumour but they never manifest as a disease and so they are not clinically significant. Option B that is Gastrinoma is the most common functional NET of pancreas associated with MEN Syndrome. Option C and D are not common NET of pancreas.

questions.text: Whipple’s triad is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) whipple’s triad is seen in Insulinoma. Whipple’s triad: Symptoms of hypoglycaemia + Blood sugar level < 40mg/dl + symptoms get relieved by oral glucose.

questions.text: MC site of gastrinoma: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) the most common site of gastrinoma is duodenum followed by pancreas. Occurrence of gastrinoma in stomach and colon is not seen.

questions.text: All are true about gastrinoma except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) in gastrinoma we have increase in basal acid output and not the decrease in basal acid output. Option A is correct as in gastrinoma we get excessive gastric acid secretion which is accompanied by occurrence of peptic ulcer at abnormal locations. Option B is correct as gastrinoma is associated with diarrhoea. Option D is correct as among the medical treatments available, best treatment option is omeprazole.

questions.text: Localization of gastrinoma is best done by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Localization of gastrinoma is best done by somatostatin receptor scintigraphy. Localization of insulinoma is best done by intraoperative palpation and USG.

questions.text: Least common site of gastrinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) We know that the most common site of gastrinoma is duodenum and within the duodenum the incidence is as follows : 1st part > 2nd part> 3rd part> 4th part. So inside the duodenum, 4th part of duodenum is the least common site for gastrinoma.

questions.text: All are true about gastrinoma except: (LQ)

Option B is correct as duodenum is the most common site for the occurrence of gastrinoma. Option C is correct as diarrhoea is an important feature of gastrinoma and this can be prevented by repeated NG tube aspiration. Option D is correct as we avoid total gastrectomy in gastrinoma. Treatment of gastrinoma comprises primarily of PPI’s and if it is situated in the distal pancreas, we go for distal pancreatectomy and if it is present in head, we go for pancreaticoduodenectomy.

questions.text: Metastatic glucagonoma is best detected by: (LQ)

questions.text: In VIPoma, not seen: (LQ)

questions.text: Gallstones are associated with which NET: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) somatostatinoma is associated with decreased motility of the gall bladder and thus predisposes to the formation of gall stones. Option A is insulinoma and it is associated with events of hypoglycaemia and not with gallstone formation. Option B that is VIPoma is associated with watery diarrhoea ,hypokalemia and achlorhydria, it is not associated with gallstone formation. Option D glucagonoma is associated with Migratory necrolytic skin rash and not with gallstone formation.

questions.text: The triad of diabetes, gallstones and steatorrhea is associated with which one of the following tumors ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Somatostatin excess causes steatorrhea (30-68%), mild diabetes (60%), cholelithiasis (70%), and hypochlorhydria (86%) so the answer to the above question is option B

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neurotensinoma cause hypokalemia, weight loss, hypotension, cyanosis, flushing and diabetes. They are usually malignant

questions.text: All are true about neuroendocrine tumor of pancreas: (PGI Nov 2013)

Option C Gastrinoma: The classic triad of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome includes (1) severe gastrointestinal ulcerative disease, (2) gastric acid hypersecretion, and (3) non beta islet cell tumors of the pancreas .Abdominal pain and peptic ulceration of the upper gastrointestinal tract are the most common symptoms Option D is correct as excess somatostatin reduces the gall bladder motility and predisposes to the formation of gall stones. questions.text: True about pseudocyst pancreas: (LQ)

questions.text: Most common complication of pseudocyst: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Infection is the most common complication of pseudocyst. Rupture is another complication of pseudocyst, if cyst ruptures in the intestine there is chance of spontaneous resolution of the pseudocyst, pseudocyst can also rupture into the peritoneal cavity, if this happens patient will present with signs of peritonitis. Pseudocyst can rupture into vessels leading to haemorrhage Pseudocyst can compress the stomach and lead to features of gastric outlet obstruction or it can compress the CBD and lead to features of obstructive jaundice . So all the above mentioned options are the complications of pseudocyst but among these the most common complication is Infection.

questions.text: Most common cause of pseudo pancreatic cyst in children is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) pancreatic pseudocyst is a circumscribed collection of fluid rich in pancreatic enzymes, blood, and necrotic tissue, typically located in the lesser sac of the abdomen. Pancreatic pseudocysts are usually complications of pancreatitis, although in children they frequently occur following abdominal trauma. Pancreatic pseudocysts account for approximately 75% of all pancreatic masses

In pseudocyst of pancreas the amylase levels are high Most common site of pseudopancreatic cyst is body and the tail of pancreas and not the head of the pancreas

questions.text: Treatment of choice for asymptomatic pseudocyst pancreas is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pancreatic pseudocyst treatment should be aimed at avoiding any complication (1 in 10 cases become infected). They also tend to rupture, and have shown that larger cysts have a higher likelihood to become more symptomatic, even needing surgery. If no signs of infection are present, initial treatment can include conservative measures such as bowel rest (NPO), parenteral nutrition (TPN), and observation. Serum amylase levels can be trended. If symptoms do not improve by 6 weeks, surgical intervention may be appropriate.

questions.text: All are features of pseudopancreatic cyst, except: (LQ)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of pseudo pancreatic cyst ? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Malignancy is not a complication of pseudocyst of pancreas . Infection is the most common complication of pseudocyst. Rupture is another complication of pseudocyst, if cyst ruptures in the intestine there is chance of spontaneous resolution of the pseudocyst, pseudocyst can also rupture into the peritoneal cavity, if this happens patient will present with signs of peritonitis. Pseudocyst can rupture into vessels leading to haemorrhage So of the above mentioned causes rupture, haemorrhage and infection are well documented complications of pseudocyst but malignancy is not a complication of pseudocyst of pancreas

questions.text: A 20-years old football player received a hard kick in the epigastrium. A large cystic swelling appeared in the epigastrium two weeks later. The most likely diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Answer to this question is undoubtedly pseudocyst of pancreas as this describes a typical scenario of traumatic pancreatitis due to blunt abdominal trauma and a complication occurring due to this in the form of pseudocyst of pancreas . Option A and B are wrong as development of hydatid cyst and amoebic liver abscess has nothing to do with the history of trauma and are infective conditions. Hematoma of rectus sheath appears as a fullness in the epigastric region rather than a cystic swelling, and if at all it was to occur it would have occurred immediately after the trauma rather than presenting 2 weeks later.

choices.text: Discolouration around the umbilicus is known as Grey – Turner’s sign
Discolouration around the inguinal ligament is known as Fox’s sign
Discolouration around the umbilicus occurs as the fluid tracks along the lesser omentum to bare area of liver and then via the falciform ligament to the umbilicus
A complication of acute pancreatitis can be ischemia of the midgut

questions.text: Among the following true statements are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Discolouration around the umbilicus is known as Cullen’s sign and in the flanks is known as Grey – Turner’s sign. These are complications of haemorrhagic pancreatitis. Haemorrhagic fluid may accumulate in the loose retroperitoneal tissues around the pancreas and track laterally to the flanks (Grey Turner’s sign), down to the inguinal ligaments (Fox’s sign), or via the lesser omentum and ‘bare area’ of the liver to the falciform ligament and the skin around the umbilicus (Cullen’s sign), manifesting as diffuse bruising. Irritation of the stomach contributes to gastric stasis and vomiting. inflammation of the superior mesenteric plexus may contribute to paralytic ileus; and vascular inflammation may cause superior mesenteric or portal vein thrombosis, arterial bleeding or pseudoaneurysms, and ischaemia of the transverse colon.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is undergoing surgical repair of a perforated duodenal ulcer. During the procedure the gastroduodenal artery is ligated. A branch of which artery will continue to supply blood to the duodenum and head of pancreas in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery will continue to supply the pancreas, particularly the head of the pancreas, if the gastroduodenal artery is compromised. This artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery. The splenic artery does not supply the head of the pancreas. The left gastric artery gives off branches to the inferior oesophagus and supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach together with the right gastric artery. The right gastric artery supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach

questions.text: A 47-year-old alcoholic man is having epigastric and midabdominal pain, which began shortly after he ate a large meal. The pain reached maximum intensity in about 12 hours and is now constant, severe, and radiating to his back. He vomited early on and has continued to retch even after his stomach was empty. Although he has discomfort when his upper abdomen is palpated, the physical exam is less impressive than the severity of his pain would suggest. He is afebrile. Serum lipase is very elevated, and hematocrit is 54. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute edematous pancreatitis occurs in the alcoholic or the patient with gallstones. Epigastric and midabdominal pain starts after a heavy meal or bout of alcoholic intake, is constant, radiates straight through to the back, and is accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and (after the stomach is empty) continued retching. There is tenderness and mild rebound in the upper abdomen. Elevated serum amylase or lipase (early on) or urinary amylase or lipase (after a couple of days) are diagnostic, and a key finding to establish the edematous nature is an elevated hematocrit. Resolution usually follows a few days of pancreatic rest (NPO, NG suction, IV fluids). Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis is a much more deadly disease. It starts as the edematous form does, but an early laboratory clue is lower hematocrit (the degree of amylase elevation does not correlate with the severity of the disease).

questions.text: The most common cause of chronic pancreatitis worldwide is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) For acute pancreatitis, gallstones and alcohol abuse are by far the two most common etiologies Alcohol abuse is by far the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis. Although hypertriglyceridemia, infection (often viral) and hereditary syndromes can lead to acute pancreatitis, they occur less frequently than alcohol abuse and gallstones.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents for evaluation of yellow skin. Review of systems is significant for loose-fitting clothes, fatigue, and night sweats. Laboratory evaluation is remarkable for elevated total bilirubin. CT scan reveals a pancreatic mass. Which of the following is least likely to contribute to this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Coffee drinking has not been shown to be a risk factor for pancreatic cancer. Factors that are associated with a risk for pancreatic cancer include smoking (strongest and accounts for 25–30% of all cases), obesity, diabetes, atypical multiple mole melanoma, hereditary pancreatitis, familial adenomatous polyposis, hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer, BRCA2, and Peutz- Jeghers syndrome. The role of alcohol in pancreatic cancer is debatable. More recently, a history of cholecystectomy and/or cholelithiasis has been demonstrated to be associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: Octreotide scanning is most useful for localization of which of the following tumors?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Many pancreatic endocrine tumors have high concentrations of somatostatin receptors and can therefore be imaged with a radiolabeled form of the somatostatin analogue octreotide Octreotide scanning has the advantage of whole-body scanning, which is useful in gastrinomas because they can present in a wide area. Used in combination with endoscopic ultrasonography, it detects more than 90% of gastrinomas. It is also useful for localizing carcinoid tumors As many as 90% of gastrinomas are found in the Passaro triangle, an area defined by the junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct, the second and third portions of the duodenum, and the neck and body of the pancreas.

choices.text: Major papilla sphincterotomy and pancreatic ductal septotomy

questions.text: The preferred definitive treatment for recurrent acute pancreatitis due to pancreas divisum is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pancreas divisum can lead to recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis as well as chronic pancreatitis with intractable pain. Unlike other forms of chronic pancreatitis, however, marked dilation of the dorsal duct is unusual. As such, surgical decompressive procedures are not successful. For patients with recurrent attacks of acute pancreatitis, the best option is sphincterotomy of the minor papilla because the duct of Santorini is providing the primary drainage to the pancreas.

questions.text: Adenocarcinoma of the pancreas arises most often from which anatomic site?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The majority of adenocarcinomas of the pancreas arise from the main pancreatic duct Approximately 66% of pancreatic adenocarcinomas develop within the head or uncinate process ofthe pancreas. The remaining answer choices can lead to pancreatic adenocarcinoma, but it occurs less frequently. Carcinoma at the ampulla of Vater is most commonly duodenal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following pancreatic cystic lesions is almost exclusively found in a young female?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Solid pseudopapillary epithelial neoplasm is a rare tumor occurring almost exclusively in young women. It has low malignant potential and for the majority of patients, the tumor can be resected with curative intent regardless of the size. Metastasis and recurrence are uncommon. Serous cystic adenoma also occurs most commonly in women, but this has no malignant potential and does not need to be resected unless it is causing mass effect.

choices.text: Most are symptomatic and present with left upper quadrant tenderness.
The patient should undergo percutaneous aspiration.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male has an incidentally discovered 8-cm nonparasitic splenic cyst. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nonparasitic splenic cysts are rare. They are most commonly asymptomatic but when patients have symptoms they frequently complain of left upper quadrant tenderness with referred pain to the left shoulder. More recently it has been shown that asymptomatic cysts can safely be observed regardless of size. Additionally, percutaneous aspiration is met with high recurrence rates. Patients should be managed with observation and serial ultrasound imaging to assess for interval growth. It has been shown that splenic cysts may secrete tumor markers such as CA 19-9, but they do not have malignant potential.

questions.text: Operation for chronic pancreatitis are the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lateral pancreaticojejunostomy (Pucstow procedure) is recommended in patients with chronic abdominal pain and dilation of the main pancreatic duct of at least 7 mm or greater in diameter. Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (Beger procedure) is indicated in patients with an inflammatory mass in the head of the pancreas, severe common bile duct stenosis (that failed biliary stenting), and in the presence of severe stenosis of the peripapillary duodenum. Frey described a modification of the duodenum preserving pancreatic head resection that requires partial coring of the ventral part of the pancreatic head, in addition to a side-to-side pancreaticojejunostomy anastomosis. This technique allows for simultaneous decompression of the intrapancreatic segment of the common bile duct in addition to drainage of the main pancreatic duct. The Frey procedure is best suited for patients with a dilation of the main pancreatic duct associated with a minor inflammatory mass in the head of the pancreas. Dohlman’s procedure is done for zenker’s diverticulum.

questions.text: According to Ranson criteria a 67-year-old female patient suspected of acute pancreatitis presenting to the ER with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, a serum aspartate transaminase (AST) >250 U/dL, a white blood cell (WBC) >16,000/mm3, and a blood glucose >200 mg/dL would receive a disease classification of
questions.solution: Correct Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with jaundice underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) as a part of her diagnostic workup. On the basis of this radiograph, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ERCP study shows the classic “double-duct sign:” dilation of the biliary system above an area of abrupt narrowing and abrupt termination of the main pancreatic duct. These findings place the primary abnormality in the geographic location of the pancreatic head, and it is not uncommon for a pancreatic neoplasm to involve both ducts.

questions.text: 68-year-old man presents with painless jaundice. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and alcohol abuse. He has a 40-pack-year tobacco history. He has been hospitalized for pancreatitis three times in the past. Computed tomography (CT) scan shows a 2-cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) and biopsy confirm pancreatic adenocarcinoma. He asks you what most likely would have contributed to this diagnosis of ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Epidemiologic studies have identified various demographic, medical, environmental, and dietary factors that have some relationship to pancreatic cancer. The most firmly established risk factor is cigarette smoking.

choices.text: The lesion is benign and requires no intervention
The lesion is malignant and probably incurable

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was seen at an outside hospital with abdominal pain, and a CT scan was performed showing a pancreatic cyst. The interventional radiologist drained the cyst during that admission, and the patient was sent home. She presents now to your hospital, and a CT scan again shows a septated, 10-cm cystic mass in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following statements constitutes appropriate advice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma are cystic neoplasms of the pancreas that are most commonly manifested as mass lesions in middle-aged women. Serous and mucinous types are recognized, and the risk for malignancy is significant with the mucinous variety. Cystadenoma is more common than its malignant counterpart, but malignant transformation may occur. EUS with sampling for cytology, mucin, and carcinoembryonic antigen can be useful for gauging the likelihood of cancer. Without resection, however, exclusion of malignancy can be difficult. Internal drainage of cystic neoplasms is not an appropriate therapy. Complete excision should be carried out whenever possible.

choices.text: Aplasia of the dorsal pancreatic anlage
Aplasia of the ventral pancreatic anlage
Incomplete rotation of the ventral pancreatic anlage
Failed fusion of the ventral and dorsal pancreatic ducts

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the emergency department (ED) with nausea, vomiting, and pain in the epigastrium and right upper quadrant (RUQ). She is afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Her WBC is 10,000 cells per MCL without a left shift, and total bilirubin is 2.5 mg/dL. The common bile duct was not identified on subsequent ultrasound due to overlying bowel gas. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) confirms a gallstone in the common bile duct with proximal dilation. Incidentally, she is found to have pancreatic divisum. What is the etiology of this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pancreas divisum currently refers to congenital variations of the pancreatic ducts that result from failed or incomplete fusion of the embryologic ventral and dorsal ductal systems. There may be complete separation of the ducts, an absent or minimal ventral duct, or only a few meager connections between the systems. As a consequence, most of the pancreatic duct drainage is through the dorsal duct joining the duodenum at the minor papilla . Any existing ventral ducts (Wirsung’s) drain only the uncinate process and the caudal head of the gland rather than the bulk of the gland at the major papilla, as when normally developed. In some individuals, it is clinically significant if the relatively stenotic minor papilla imposes an obstruction to ductal flow. This can potentially result in recurrent abdominal pain, acute pancreatitis, or even chronic pancreatitis. The diagnosis is usually made by ERCP, and cannulation of the minor papilla may be required to image the dorsal duct. MRCP might also demonstrate this ductal anatomy. The vast majority (95%) of individuals with pancreas divisum are asymptomatic

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with recurrent alcoholic pancreatitis presents to the ED with 3 days of worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Further questioning elicits symptoms including rigors and subjective fevers. His temperature is 102.5°F, WBC is 23,000 cells per MCL, heart rate is 105 beats/ min, and blood pressure is 118/64 mmHg. CT scan is obtained, which shows a hypoenhancing pancreas with necrosis and air bubbles, a small pseudocyst, and a second peripancreatic fluid collection. Which of the following complications of acute pancreatitis is associated with the highest mortality rate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Retroperitoneal infection is a serious, often fatal, complication of acute pancreatitis. Pancreatic necrosis is a manifestation of severe pancreatitis. When accompanied by infection, it has been associated with a mortality rate that may exceed 40%, which is higher than that for noninfected necrosis. Infected pancreatic necrosis is treated by operative debridement and open or closed retroperitoneal drainage. Patients with sterile necrosis may require operative intervention as well but are generally treated nonoperatively with intensive support as long as their condition permits.

choices.text: Branch duct type with mural nodularity
Branch duct type smaller than 3 cm
Main duct type with diffuse dilation to greater than 10 mm
Main duct type with segmental dilation

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to his primary care physician (PCP) with abdominal pain in the epigastrium and associated nausea. No other significant findings are observed. The patient denies any alcohol or tobacco use. The PCP sends him to the ED for a CT scan, which shows a lesion in the pancreas. The patient subsequently undergoes an EUS/ ERCP, which shows mucin at the ampulla. MRI and biopsy results confirm a main duct–type IPMN. Which of the following features of IPMN of the pancreas is associated with the lowest risk for cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Progression of IPMN through the adenoma cancer sequence is considered a slow process that requires perhaps 10 to 20 years. Main duct–type tumors have a greater risk for malignancy than the branch duct type. the following features as risk factors for cancer and as general indicators for resection: main pancreatic duct dilation to greater than 10 mm, cyst size larger than 3 cm, presence of mural nodules, and atypical cytology. Additional risk factors include high-grade dysplasia, multifocal or synchronous tumors, and increasing cyst size during follow-up. In branch duct–type tumors, mural nodularity or atypical cytology may be more important determinants than size.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to your office with a new onset of vague epigastric pain and jaundice. She denies any weight loss. To her knowledge, this has not happened before. Lab results are significant for a WBC of 12,000 cells per MCL and a total bilirubin of 2.0 mg/dL. You send her to the emergency room for a CT scan. Subsequent ERCP showed areas of irregular narrowing throughout the intrapancreatic common bile duct. No masses are identified on EUS. What is the initial treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Autoimmune pancreatitis can be very difficult to diagnose and is the cause of acute pancreatitis in 4%–6% of cases. Patient age varies between 30 and 70 years, and it affects men more often than women. The majority (70%–80%) present with painless jaundice. Acute pain, typical of classic pancreatitis, is rare. On CT or USG, a boggy, thick, “sausage-shaped” pancreas can be seen often with a rim of hypo- or hyperattenuation (early versus late). Immunoglobulin G4 levels are thought to be associated with autoimmune pancreatitis, but using levels as a diagnostic marker is highly debated. Antinuclear antibody levels may also be elevated, indicating an autoimmune process. Steroids are considered as standard therapy for this etiology of pancreatitis (typically 30 to 40 mg of prednisone for 1 week)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with an extensive history of recurrent alcoholic pancreatitis presents to the ED with progressively worsening shortness of breath. His last attack of pancreatitis was 9 months ago. At that time, a new fluid collection around the pancreas and extensive calcifications throughout the pancreas were noted. On examination, he is saturating 94% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs reveals absent breath sounds two-thirds of the way up his left lung fields. The right chest has breath sounds throughout. X-ray shows a large left pleural effusion. WBC count is 6,000 cells per MCL, and the patient is afebrile and hemodynamically stable. He has vague abdominal pain and had one episode of emesis in the ED. CT chest/abdomen displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pancreatic–pleural fistula is a very rare entity and complication of chronic/recurrent pancreatitis. This usually evolves from a disruption in the pancreatic duct (often posterior), followed by fluid tracking in the retroperitoneum and up along the aorta or esophagus into the pleural space. Initial non operative therapy can include nil per oral status, total parenteral nutrition, repeat thoracentesis, and octreotide. Interventional therapy utilizing ERCP to stent the ductal defect (if present) may also be attempted. Operative therapy for failed conservative therapy, including duct ligation and resection or Roux-en- Y reconstruction, has an efficacy of 90% with an 18% recurrence. Regardless of treatment modality, patients often require prolonged hospitalization. Currently, treatment consists of several weeks of conservative management before progressing to surgical intervention
